questions.text: 1. A patient comes to the ER with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, sweating, and blood in stools initially, which later became watery. The patient also complains of throat pain followed by purging and vomiting. Vomitus contains bile and blood, and he also has a garlicky odour. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a garlicky odor is highly suggestive of acute arsenic (gastroenteric type) poisoning.

The gastroenteric variant of acute arsenic poisoning, which is the most common type, resembles bacterial food poisoning. Symptoms usually appear half to one hour after ingestion. The symptoms include:

* Constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing;

* Burning and colicky pain in the esophagus, stomach, and bowel.

* Intense thirst and severe vomiting, which may be projectile.

* Purging (within 1 to 3 hours) is usually accompanied by tenesmus, pain.

* The stools are expelled frequently and involuntarily, and are dark-coloured, stinking, and bloody, but later become colourless, odourless, and watery, resembling rice-water stools of cholera. 

* A garlicky odour of breath and faeces may be noted.

Oliguria, uraemia, and acute circulatory collapse are the causes of death. 

In fulminant cases, i.e., massive doses (3 to 5 gm) of arsenic when rapidly absorbed, cause death in 1 to 3 hours from shock and peripheral vascular failure.

Treatment of arsenic poisoning includes repeated stomach wash with warm water and milk, small doses of freshly precipitated hydrated ferric oxide to convert toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite, BAL with penicillamine, DMSA (succimer) or DMPS as superior alternatives, haemodialysis or exchange transfusion in renal failure, while chelation therapy is ineffective.

Other options: 

Option B: Acute phosphorus poisoning that is mainly caused by white phosphorus, which is the most toxic form of phosphorus, mimics arsenic poisoning with similar GI symptoms and garlicky odor. However, luminescent vomit and faeces are diagnostic.

Option C: In acute aluminium phosphide poisoning, the phosphine gas causes predominantly respiratory symptoms and distress, rather than GI symptoms.

Option D: Croton seeds (jamalgota) cause hot burning pain from the mouth to the stomach, salivation, vomiting, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death. Applied to the skin, it produces burning, redness, and vesication. There is no garlicky odor.

questions.solution:
Zasko’s phenomenon is the tendon reflex occurring after death.

Zasko’s phenomenon or Tendon reaction is the upward movement of the patella because of the contraction of the entire muscle of quadriceps muscle.

It is seen up to 1 to 2 hrs after death. It is elicited by striking the lower third of the quadriceps femoris muscle 10 cm above the patella with a reflex hammer.

questions.text: 3. During the autopsy of a 35-year-old female, the doctor noted bruises below the right angle of the mandible with a curved scratch on the right side and three grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage, and additional bruises over the head, shoulder blade, backside of the trunk, and left iliac crest. Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage is present. What is the likely cause of the death?
questions.solution:
The likely cause of death in the given case is throttling (manual strangulation).

Both bruising around the neck and the fracture of the thyroid cartilage are findings seen in throttling. Throttling/manual strangulation is when bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate.

Mechanism of death:

* Occlusion of blood vessels supplying blood to the brain (carotid arteries).

* Occlusion of the airway probably plays a minor role, if any, in causing death.

* Carotid sinus pressure may result in vagus nerve stimulation, resulting in cardiac arrest (vagal inhibition).

External examination findings in autopsy:

* Bruises on the neck: finger grip marks from the assailant, such as bruises below the right angle of the mandible and grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage.

* Abrasions/fingernail marks: curved scratch mark on the right side of the neck due to nail pressure.

* Petechial hemorrhages in the eyes: due to venous congestion from compression of neck vessels.

* Absence of ligature mark: rules out ligature strangulation, supporting manual compression of the neck.

* Additional bruises on the head, shoulder blade, backside of trunk, and left iliac crest suggest a struggle/assault consistent with homicidal violence.

Internal examination findings in autopsy:

* Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage is a classical finding in throttling.

* Carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma: further evidence of forceful neck compression.

* Inward fracture of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone may also be encountered

Thumb impression and finger marks, as shown in the image below, are seen in the case of throttling:



The following image shows the autopsy findings in a case of throttling:



Other options:

Option A: Garroting is a form of ligature strangulation where a thin string is thrown around the neck and is then tightened rapidly with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string to constrict the neck. The image below shows garroting.



Option C: Ligature strangulation is strangulation done by using a ligature, like a constricting band or rope. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth. 

Option D: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In a mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. questions.text: 4. According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012, protection against sexual harassment, sexual offences, and pornography is provided to?
questions.solution:
According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012, protection against sexual harassment, sexual offences, and pornography is provided to all children (both male and female) under the age of 18.

As per the POCSO Act, 2012, all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years are considered children and are protected from sexual abuse. 

The offenses and respective punishments in the provisions of this act are as follows:

S. No. Offense Punishment If aggravated
1. Penetrative sexual assault Imprisonment for 7 or more years; May extend for life with a fine. Imprisonment for 10 years or more; May extend for life with a fine.
2. Sexual assault without penetration Imprisonment for ≥ 3-5 years and fine Imprisonment for ≥ 5-7 years and fine
3. Sexual harassment Imprisonment for 3 years and a fine  
4. Child pornography

Imprisonment for 5 years and a fine.

A subsequent conviction is liable to 7 years of imprisonment and a fine.

  


Sexual abuse offenses, when committed by a person in a position of authority over the child (police/ member of security forces/ public servant), are deemed to be aggravated.

All sexual offenses must be reported to the police as a rule. Failure to comply with this mandatory provision of the POCSO Act can attract imprisonment for up to 6 months, a fine, or both.

questions.text: 5. The parents of a 16-year-old girl are alleging kidnapping and rape charges against a 25-year-old man. The accused says he loves the girl and wants to marry her, and that the sexual activity was consensual. The girl also agrees that it was consensual. Examination confirms recent sexual activity, but there are no injuries. What is the likely legal problem under Indian law?

choices.text: No offense since the man says he loves the girl and wants to marry her
Parents should prove that there was an assault and physical resistance
No offense since no injuries present
Consent is immaterial since the girl is less than 18 years old

questions.solution:
The most likely legal issue under Indian law in this case is that the consent is immaterial since the girl is less than 18 years old.

According to Section 63(d)(vi) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), previously Section 375(d)(6) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), sexual intercourse with a girl below 18 years is treated as statutory rape, even if she gives consent. 

As per Section 63(d) of BNS, application of a man's mouth to the vagina, anus, or urethra of a woman, or making her do so with him or another person, is considered rape under the following circumstances:

* Against her will.

* Without her consent.

* With her consent obtained by putting her or someone she cares for in fear of death or hurt.

* With her consent, when he knows he is not her husband, but she believes him to be the man she is lawfully married to.

* With her consent, when, due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or administration of a stupefying substance, she cannot understand the nature or consequences of that consent.

* With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.

* When she is unable to communicate consent.

questions.text: 6. A 35-year-old assaults his co-worker in the office. He was of the opinion that his co-worker was going to kill him, as he heard from voices in his ear. The patient appears dishevelled, with disorganised speech. What is the best course of legal action?

choices.text: Declare him not guilty due to mental illness
Refer the patient for comprehensive psychiatric evaluation

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the best course of legal action is referring the accused for a comprehensive psychiatric evaluation.

As per the given scenario, the accused appears to be of unsound mind. According to section 368(2) of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS), previously, section 329 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), if, during a trial, the Magistrate or Court of Session finds the accused to be of unsound mind, they must refer such a person to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist for assessment and care. The concerned professional will then submit a report regarding the accused's mental condition, guiding further legal proceedings.

Other options:

Option A: As per Bharat Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 22, nothing is an offence if done by an individual who, at the time of the act, is of unsound mind. Hence, proceeding with a routine trial without establishing or ruling out unsoundness of mind is not correct.

Option B: The court cannot declare the accused not guilty due to mental illness without obtaining a report regarding the accused's psychiatric evaluation, as this would be a violation of section 368(2) of BNSS.

Option D: In this case, the patient's behavior points towards a mental illness rather than mere anger; hence, referring the patient for anger management is not the most appropriate legal course of action.
